comments.body:
I am impressed and happy that this now works without having to manually `go get` more tooling.

I'm not sure if this is something to be fixed, but when I do the initial go get, I see some output:
```
$ go get k8s.io/kubernetes
package k8s.io/kubernetes: no buildable Go source files in /root/go/src/k8s.io/kubernetes
$
```
Not sure if we want to mention it, or find a way to clean it up. (Maybe it's understood that this will happen?)
I guess we could do `go get -d k8s.io/kubernetes` that should avoid the warning message as it won't try to build.
@michelleN We'll need to update these links when the developer docs are moved.

comments.body: Hm, maybe "decade and a half of experience running production workloads at Google scale" flows a tiny bit better?
That text is copied all over. I could fix it, but I'm not sure it's worth it right now. I'm focused on content.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +19,23 @@* **self-healing**: auto-placement, auto-restart, auto-replication

Kubernetes builds upon a [decade and a half of experience at Google running production workloads at scale](https://research.google.com/pubs/pub43438.html), combined with best-of-breed ideas and practices from the community.

<hr>

comments.body:
And https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/kubernetes/blob/master/docs/glossary.md

It would help to have an outline of what we wanted.

Fair comment :) I'm trying to clean up the information so that it's more clear. We have a lot of good info that's spread out and hard to find - the docs/overview.md, for example, has good info that can be merged into some of the other overview style pages (or built out to be _the_ overview of the project).

Initially I'd like to concentrate on two things:

1 - consolidating pages
2 - increasing discoverability and giving some indication of the order in which to read the docs
(okay that's three things :) )

Each folder should have a readme that describes its contents. The list of docs in the docs/readme.md is great; we also need to list out/describe the pages that are in that folder.
I get the high-level goal. I was hoping for more of a sketch of where you're going with this, but I can wait for that..
Note that an overview issue, #2633, has been filed.

comments.body: I'd add a note that this only works with a local Docker daemon.  Remote Docker configurations (including `boot2docker` on Mac OS X) won't work.

that will not work, when running `boot2docker` has the volume are on the host (and not on your workstation).

Instead you could consider having the doc directory be the context of the build.

@@ -1,1 +7,11 @@### Prerequisites

1. You need a Google Cloud Platform account with billing enabled. Visit [http://cloud.google.com/console]() for more details
2. You must have Go installed: [www.golang.org](http://www.golang.org).
3. Ensure that your `gcloud` components are up-to-date by running `gcloud components update`.
